name: tantalum powder production, capacitor-grade | tantalum powder, capacitor-grade | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24568/documentation

This dataset refers to the extraction and reduction processes applied in the produced tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5) in order to produce 1 kg of pure tantalum powder in China. China is responsible for approximately 48% of the global tantalum powder production, according to Achebe, J. (2016). This dataset is a disaggregation of the activity ''tantalum production, powder, capacitor-grade'' as found in version 3.7 of the Ecoinvent database that produces tantalum powder from tantalite ore and has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography GLO, due to absence of regionalized dataset.;;The original data for reduction were provided from a patent from HC Stark Germany. For both the extraction and the refining processes the data were taken from tables 5.5 & 5.7 or already aggregated from figure 5.4, part XI of the Classen et al (2009) report. Specific values were adjusted to reflect today's situation. (consult the sampling procedure and the individual exchange comments). The amount of tantalum concentrate has been adjusted due to the fact that the original datasets assumed a grade of 38% Ta2O5, while in this dataset a grade of 30% is considered (for the calculation of the amount consult the respective exchange comment). Other tantalum sources used for the production of pure tantalum powder (from consumer scrap or from tantalum byproduct stemming from tin production) has not been taken into account. Furthermore, the present dataset is meant to be used exclusively in the context of electronic devices, since tantalum production for alloying purposes follows a different production route (for more in-formation, Fig. 5.1 of the abovementioned source is to be consulted).;;Reference 1: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmeneg-ger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.;;Reference 2: Achebe, J. (2016). Substance Flow Analysis of Tantalum: Tracking the Conflict-Free Path. In: UWSpace. Link: https://uwspace.uwaterloo.ca/bitstream/handle/10012/10582/Achebe_Jessica.pdf?sequence=3%26isAllowed).

The activities start with the processing of tantalum concentrate.

The activities end with the production of pure tantalum powder.

No allocation is applied.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals/2420:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The production of tantalum powder has not undergone significant changes. Therefore, the data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset considered valid for the entire corresponding region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: After the production of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5), it is digested at high temperature through the use of hydrofluoric and sulfuric acid. The produced Ta solution is filtered - thus removing the insoluble minerals – and then undergoes liquid-liquid separation (solvent extraction) using methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK) to separate niobium from tantalum. The MIBK in tantalum is stripped from the solution and tantalum is precipitated as hydroxide by adding ammonia (NH3). Then, the hydroxide is calcined in a furnace to produce pure tantalum oxide. The pure tantalum oxide is later reduced to pure tantalum powder by bringing the pure tantalum oxide in contact with magnesium vapour, in a multiple hearth furnace or rotary kiln. The stoichiometric equation is the following: Ta2O5 + 5Mg -> 5MgO + 2Ta. The unreacted magnesium is assumed to be recovered. Sulfuric acid and ultrapure water are then utilized to remove the magnesium oxide, producing magnesium sulfate which is removed from the solution and therefore serves as a by-product that can be further processed.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The data originated from a patent from the company HC Stark and have been extrapolated to represent the production of tantalum powder in China, due to absence of regionalized data.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset refers to the extraction and reduction processes applied in the produced tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5) in order to produce 1 kg of pure tantalum powder in China. China is responsible for approximately 48% of the global tantalum powder production, according to Achebe, J. (2016). This da-taset is a disaggregation of the activity ''tantalum production, powder, capacitor-grade'' as found in version 3.7 of the Ecoinvent database that produces tantalum powder from tantalite ore and has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography GLO, due to absence of regionalized dataset.

The original data for reduction were provided from a patent from HC Stark Germany. For both the extraction and the refining processes the data were taken from tables 5.5 & 5.7 or already aggregated from figure 5.4, part XI of the Classen et al (2009) report. Specific values were adjusted to reflect today's situation. (consult the sampling procedure and the individual exchange comments). The amount of tantalum concentrate has been adjusted due to the fact that the original datasets assumed a grade of 38% Ta2O5, while in this dataset a grade of 30% is considered (for the calculation of the amount consult the respective exchange comment). Other tantalum sources used for the production of pure tantalum powder (from consumer scrap or from tantalum byproduct stemming from tin production) has not been taken into account. Furthermore, the present dataset is meant to be used exclusively in the context of electronic devices, since tantalum production for alloying purposes follows a different production route (for more in-formation, Fig. 5.1 of the abovementioned source is to be consulted).

Reference 1: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmeneg-ger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.

Reference 2: Achebe, J. (2016). Substance Flow Analysis of Tantalum: Tracking the Conflict-Free Path. In: UWSpace. Link: https://uwspace.uwaterloo.ca/bitstream/handle/10012/10582/Achebe_Jessica.pdf?sequence=3%26isAllowed).

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of ultrapure water required during the magnesium reduction process for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. The original value is 2 kg (required for the cleaning of magnesium oxide) and was taken from Table 5.7, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, due to the diluted sulfuric acid added during the magnesium reduction process (assumed dilution 10% w/w - see sulfuric accid exchange comment), ultrapure water for the dilution of sulfuric acid is required. Based on the 10% w/w dilution, the amount of ultrapure water is 3*0.9=2.7 kg. The amount of the above-calculated ultrapure water will be added to the existing one (2 kg), because the existing one is used for cleaning the removed magnesium oxide. As a result the final amount of ultrapure water will be 4.7 kg. 
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
This exchange represents the amount of sulfuric acid required during the extraction (3 kg) and magnesium reduction process (3 kg) for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. These values are taken from Tables 5.5 & 5.7, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, the abovementioned amount of sulfuric acid input for the extraction process is used for the processing of the tantalum concentrate with 38% Ta2O5 content, while the average grade today is assumed to be 30% (see mining and beneficiation dataset of tantalum). To tackle this issue, it is assumed that for a less pure concentrate, more amount of sulfuric acid would be required (the amount of sulfuric acid would therefore be inversely proportional to the grade of concentrate). After this adjustment, the amount of sulfuric acid is multiplied by 1.22, because 1.22 kg of purified tantalum pentoxide is required for the production of 1 kg pure tantalum powder. The sulfuric acid required in the magnesium reduction process (3 kg) is reported in table 5.7 as diluted sulfuric acid. However, no information on the dilution is given. For that reason, it is assumed that the dilution is 10% w/w (Source: <https://www.cs.mcgill.ca/~rwest/wikispeedia/wpcd/wp/s/Sulfuric_acid.htm>), meaning that meaning that the active substance is 3*0.1= 0.3 kg and the rest (3*0.9 =2.7 kg) will be the ultrapure water.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
This exchange represents the amount of magnesium required during the magnesium reduction process for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. The original amount of this input is 0.369 kg and is taken from Table 5.7, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, due to the fact that the unreacted magnesium (0.0369 kg - according to table 5.7 of the abovementioned source) is supposed to be recovered, the net amount of magnesium is 0.336 kg (see chapter 5.1.4 for tantalum powder production of the abovementioned source).

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of heat required during the extraction process for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. The original amount of this exchange was 0.23 MJ and was taken from Table 5.5, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. The amount of heat is multiplied by 1.22, because 1.22 kg of purified tantalum pentoxide is required for the production of 1 kg pure tantalum powder. No adjustment of the inputs with the ore grades has been done, since the amount of energy is calculated based on the stoichiometric amount of the input.

EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of ammonia required during the extraction process for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. The original amount of this exchange was 0.7 kg and was taken from Table 5.5, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, the abovementioned amount of ammonia input is used for the processing of the tantalum concentrate with 38% Ta2O5 content, while the average grade today is assumed to be 30% (see mining and beneficiation dataset of tantalum). To tackle this issue, it is assumed that for a less pure concentrate, more amount of ammonia would be required (the amount of ammonia would therefore be inversely proportional to the grade of concentrate). Finally, after this adjustment, the amount of ammonia is multiplied by 1.22, because 1.22 kg of purified tantalum pentoxide is required for the production of 1 kg pure tantalum powder.

exchanges.description: This exchange represents tha amount of tantalum concentrate required for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. The value is calculated the follwoing way: During the extraction process, 2.77 kg of tantalum concentrate with 38% Ta2O5 is required for the production of 1 kg of purifired tantalum pentoxide. This means that 3.3794 kg of tantalum pentoxide are required for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. The abovementioned values can be found in tables 5.5 and 5.7 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, the tantalum concentrate on the original dataset in the abovementioned source is 38%, while the average grade today is assumed to be 30% (see mining and beneficiation dataset of tantalum). In order to enure that the same Ta2O5 content in the concentrate is processed, the 3.3794 kg is multiplied by (0.38/0.30) in order to obtain the amount of concentrate input with 30% Ta2O5.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of hydrogen fluoride required during the extraction process for the production of 1 kg of pure tantalum powder. The original amount of this exchange was 2 kg and was taken from Table 5.5, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, the abovementioned amount of hydrogen fluoride input is used for the processing of the tantalum concentrate with 38% Ta2O5 content, while the average grade today is assumed to be 30% (see mining and beneficiation dataset of tantalum). To tackle this issue, it is assumed that for a less pure concentrate, more amount of hydrogen fluoride would be required (the amount of hydrogen fluoride would therefore be inversely proportional to the grade of concentrate). Finally, after this adjustment, the amount of hydrogen fluoride is multiplied by 1.22, because 1.22 kg of purified tantalum pentoxide is required for the production of 1 kg pure tantalum powder.

EcoSpold01Location=GLO
